Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: New Curriculum and Undergraduate Research in Applied Mathematics at Tennessee State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Department of Mathematical Sciences at Tennessee State University has as its goal to develop and implement an applied mathematics program, which is designed to fill the gap between mathematics and other STEM areas. This will be achieved using a set of strategically constructed interventions that include, but are not limited to development of new courses and curricula related to applied mathematics, institutionalization of a new concentration in applied mathematics for undergraduate mathematics majors and enhancement of research experiences. Collectively, these strategies are expected to increase the overall number of mathematics majors at the institution by 10%, and build the science capacity and infrastructure of the institution such that the mathematical and technological skills of the entire undergraduate population are enhanced. As such, Tennessee State University is uniquely poised to contribute to diversifying the US STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Targeted Infusion Project #1238775: New Curriculum and Undergraduate Research in Applied Mathematics at Tennessee State University

 

This project enabled the Mathematical Sciences Department at Tennessee State University to do (a) an in-depth study of the bachelor degree in Mathematical Sciences curriculum, (b) summer research workshops for HBCU’s STEM students, and (c) university wide colloquiums in applied mathematics.

The bachelor degree in Mathematical Sciences curriculum at TSU was significantly improved and now adheres to the standards proposed by the Mathematical Association of America (M.A.A.). In addition, the project redesigned existing mathematics courses and implemented new courses for both Applied Mathematics and Statistics. These changes were supported by the development of a state-of-the-art applied mathematics computer laboratory as part of the project.

The project also developed and conducted Summer Research Workshops in Applied Mathematics during the summers of 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016. The topics included Mathematical Biology, Control Theory, Computational Mathematics, and Applied Mathematics. Short version of newly developed courses such as Mathematical Modeling, Introduction to Scientific Computation, Methods in Applied Mathematics, and Partial Differential Equations were taught to the participants of the summer workshops. The Summer Research Workshops included participants from nine different HBCUs and eighty percent of the participants were underrepresented minority students from Albany State University, Benedict College, Central State University, Claflin University, Florida A&M University, Norfolk State University, Philander Smith College, Tennessee State University, and University of Maryland Eastern Shore. The unique practical training provided in the Workshops helped participants to be better prepared and be more competitive candidates to pursue either a STEM career or further graduate studies.

 The project organized university-wide applied mathematics seminars for STEM students from 2013—2015 and co-organized the first Annual Data Sciences Workshop at TSU reaching over 400 students. These included researchers from the Citadel College, East Tennessee State University, John Hopkins University, National Institute for Mathematical and Biological Synthesis, University of Cincinnati, University of Dayton, University of Delaware, University of Illinois - Urbana Champaign, University Of Missouri-Kansas City, University of Wisconsin at Stevens-Point, Vanderbilt University, Western Kentucky University, and Xavier University.

In this way, the project incremented applied mathematics research opportunities for undergraduate STEM majors of the entire HBCU community. The results of the project were disseminated in the form of publications in scientific journals, presentations at conferences, and a website maintained specifically for this purpose.
